items.content_html:
Description

The Sec-Fetch-Dest: image header value refers (I assume erroneously) to the <image> HTML element rather than the <img> element.

Motivation

Currently clicking this links brings you to https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/image for the deprecated <image> tag, which is unhelpful.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: fix HTML reference to in Sec-Fetch-Dest docs

items.content_html:
Description

updateWith() method is defined on PaymentRequestUpdateEvent and PaymentMethodChangeEvent simply inherit this method from PaymentRequestUpdateEvent

PaymentInstrument is a non-standard dictionary and hasn't its own documentation

payerdetailchange event is fired on PaymentResponse rather then PaymentRequest

PaymentShippingOption is a non-standard dictionary and hasn't its own documentation

PaymentDetailsModifier is a dictionary and hasn't its own documentation

AddressErrors is a non-standard dictionary and hasn't its own documentation

retry() and complete() methods are on PaymentResponse

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Fix broken links in Payment API

items.content_html:
Description

Chrome 120 adds several updates to the FedCM API (see https://chromestatus.com/feature/5177628008382464 and https://chromestatus.com/feature/5384360374566912).

This PR adds/modifies:

  • The Login Status API:
    • Navigator.login
    • NavigatorStatus
    • NavigatorStatus.setStatus()
    • The Set-Login HTTP header
  • The Error API, which mainly manifests as useful properties of the return error object when a FedCM get() call rejects.
  • The Auto-Selected Flag, which mainly manifests as the IdentityCredential.isAutoSelected property.
  • IdentityProvider.close(), which is not part of the above ChromeStatuses, but is related and not documented, so I decided to deal with it as part of this workstream.

Note also:

  • I have taken this opportunity to split up the FedCM landing page into separate guides, as it was getting quite huge and unwieldy. The FedCM landing page now has two subpages, one that covered IdP integration, and one that covers the RP sign-in flow. These seem to work well as separate items.
  • I've included the Login Status API as a part of the IdP integration guide. There is an argument to put it in its own separate API tree, but currently, only FedCM uses it, and it is also part of the FedCM spec.

See also my research document for more details of what changes were added.

Motivation

Additional details

Fixes mdn/mdn#501

Related BCD update: mdn/browser-compat-data#21721

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Technical review: Add content on FedCM Login Status API, Error API and isAutoSelected

items.content_html:
Target release: Firefox 122
Release date: Jan 23, 2024

Description

The following preferences have been enabled by default in Firefox 122:

  • ray(): layout.css.motion-path-ray.enabled
  • offset-position: layout.css.motion-path-offset-position.enabled
  • offset-path:
    • layout.css.motion-path-basic-shapes.enabled
    • layout.css.motion-path-coord-box.enabled
    • layout.css.motion-path-url.enabled

Changes

  • Experimental features: Removed entries for ray(), offset-position, and url()
  • 122: Added notes for default availability of the above features
  • ray: Removed experimental banner. Added "Formal syntax" (latest version is available in webref now).

Related issues and pull requests

  • Doc issue: #31099
  • BCD PR: mdn/browser-compat-data#21844
  • Firefox bugs:
    https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1598151
    https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1598152
    https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1598159
items.title: docs(relnote): FF122 - Support enabled for motion path features

items.content_html:
Description

This PR adds a small clarification to the expected outcome from one of the exercises without giving away the solution.

Motivation

The exercise eludes to use of the modulo operator to test for divisibility, but the linked guide does not clarify that zero is a positive result for this test and non zero is a negative result. Newcomers, while understanding division, may not understand how this relates to the modulo operator without a prompt as to expected results. Informing them that they should store 0 for even and 1 for odd, combined with the link to the page containing info that includes modulo, should be sufficient for the non mathematically inclined to piece together the method for themselves, without being too easy, or telling them which operator is required.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Clarify expected output in all cases

items.title: Macros: split quicklinks into sidebars and link pages

items.content_html:
Following on from #31453, this PR replaces all remaining rgba()/hsla() occurrences with rgb()/hsl() and updates all remaining rgb()/hsl() occurrences to use the latest syntax, within files\en-us\web

See #30844 for more details on why these changes are being made.

Included in these changes is:

  • Reword api\canvas_api\tutorial\applying_styles_and_colors to use rgb instead of rgba and include a percentage value for alpha, and rename referenced canvas_rgba.png → canvas_rgb.png
  • Remove reference to rgba in html\element\input\color

I have also left some instances of rgba/hsla in mathml\mathcolor, as it lists all the possible ways of using color, including rgb and rgba, new and old syntax, and also accessibility\understanding_color_and_luminance as it is referencing it as legacy syntax.
items.title: Update remaining web area to use latest rgb() and hsl() syntax

items.content_html:
⚠️ This is a draft because the demo doesn’t work with client-side rendered playground yet

Description

Declarative shadow DOM reuses the <template> element for generating shadow root in the presence of the shadowrootmode attribute. This element is no longer for templating only, that needs to be reflected, too.

Motivation

To support existing implementations in Chrome and Safari and prepare for the upcoming Firefox support.

Related issues and pull requests

  • #31102
items.title: Update template element description and add shadowrootmode attribute

items.title: Draft: CSS content update: learn to support older browsers

items.content_html:
Description

Remove OPTIONS from the example of Access-Control-Allow-Methods.

Motivation

OPTIONS is never actually necessary to my understanding so I think it is a bad example.

Additional details

  • https://www.w3.org/TR/2020/SPSD-cors-20200602/#access-control-allow-methods-response-header
  • https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66926518/should-access-control-allow-methods-include-options

The official spec doesn't explicitly state one way or the other to my knowledge, however it does include examples which do not include OPTIONS.

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Remove OPTIONS from Access-Control-Allow-Methods example
